text: Thank you, Sam.

Good afternoon and a
warm welcome to all.

Class of 2023, today represents
a peak in our journey.

It deserves a celebration
like no other.

As we revel in this
triumph, we also

want to reflect
on the path we've
taken in the past two years.

We are the largest class in
Harvard Business School's

history, with over
1,000 students.

We are also the first
class to have a Section K.
Where are you at, Section K?
[APPLAUSE]
In decades.

When we stepped into HBS
as first year students

in the middle of
the pandemic, we

were masked and
socially distanced.

Now, we are leaving
after a second year
that felt very normal.

You all have reactivated
our community,

from small group dinners to the
Retail and Luxury Goods Club

fashion show, from the 50th
African-American Student Union

Conference, to all the
amazing treks organized
throughout the world.

We came back stronger, more
inclusive, and more resilient.

Needless to say, the class of
2023 has seen ups and downs.

We have celebrated the highs
and come together in the lows.

But this journey
of highs and lows

isn't unique to just
our time at HBS.

Rather, it's a
reminder of the rhythm

we've been dancing for the
greater part of our lives.

During our formative
years, from youth to today,

we witnessed moments of
extreme success and innovation,
which we call the highs.

But we also witnessed
moments of pain, angst,
and suffering-- the lows.
The lows cut especially deep--

the 2008 Great Recession,
systemic racism and police

brutality, gun violence,
the war in Ukraine,

COVID, an insurrection,
extreme weather events,

and the current job
market we're going into.

But the highs have
been transformative
for our generation--

technological
innovation, the rise

of the Black Lives Matter
movement, marriage equality,

the explosion of solar
and renewable energy,

and, of course, the
world's collaboration
to end the pandemic.

And perhaps, that
is our legacy--

a generation of leaders who
is uniquely prepared to ride
the roller coaster of life.

Collectively, we have witnessed
the heights of success
and the depths of adversity.

And personally, we've
each experienced

our individual
achievements and setbacks.

And of course, in
a group of 1,000,

we are never each
experiencing our highest highs

and lowest lows
at the same time.

In fact, many
times, we don't know

when the person right next
to us may be at their lowest.

For instance, over the
past couple of months,

I've been dealing with a
personal medical issue that

has arguably marked
one of the most
difficult periods of my life.

I'd be lying if I said it
was easy to get through.
I was struggling.

I blame myself for my
situation and retreated,

declining meetings,
missing social events,

and avoiding those
closest to me.

However, through
the love and support

of my family, friends, peers
at HBS, faculty and staff,

a huge thank you to
Suzy Conway and SAS.

I'm standing here
today with you all.

My reflection is
that personal resolve

is rarely enough to overcome
life's greatest setbacks.

Instead of suffering
alone, I wish

I would have found stability
and comfort amidst life's

unpredictable nature by
leaning on my people sooner.

A reality of life,
classmates, is

that it will be full
of twists and turns,

but we should remind ourselves
of the constants in life--

those that matter
the most to us.

So let's latch onto our
communities and love deeply
and firmly, fiercely.

Let's not take
others for granted.

This will help us stay
grounded as leaders

and find deeper meaning in our
achievements during the highs

and provided us with the
strength to persevere,

the resilience to bounce
back, and the patience

to endure when inevitable
setbacks come in our journey.

So today, as we stand
here amid this triumph,

I'm reminded of my
beloved grandmother,

whose unwavering belief in the
power of education and service

propelled me toward HBS as a way
to follow my passion of lifting
Puerto Rico.

She's no longer with us,
and I miss her deeply.

But her legacy continues
to inspire me every day.

And I couldn't have
done this without her.

And in that vein, I say,
classmates, look around.

We could not have gotten
here without our loved ones.

And we will not get through
life, at what life will throw
at us, without them either.

And so on behalf of
the class of 2023,

thank you, parents,
partners, siblings,

grandparents, friends,
and, of course, children

for helping us get into HBS,
navigate our journeys here,

and graduate from
this amazing place.

We are so grateful to
you today and always.

And for that, let's
give it up to you.
[APPLAUSE]

Before we end, we also want
to thank our student executive
team.

If you are on the SA exec
team, can you please stand up?

And I'll wait for
you all to stand.
Oh, yes.

Let's just give them
a round of applause.
[APPLAUSE]

We thank you for all
of your hard work

and the countless
hours that you've

devoted to making our experience
a truly memorable one.

You planned events that brought
us together and worked closely

with student leaders
and faculty to help
rebuild our vibrant community.

We are also grateful to the
administration, especially

Matt, Jana, Barbara, Mike,
and Ellen for partnering
with and believing in us.

As we move forward,
let's continue

to cherish these connections,
investing our time, love,

and attention in
those who matter most.

We wish the class of 2023
much success and happiness.

Thank you once again,
and congratulations.
[APPLAUSE]
